reference: Volume Three, Issue Thirty-Three, File 6 of 13
title: International Toll-free, Local Rated, and Specially Toll Services
historical_context: This article provides a comprehensive overview of international toll-free and specialty phone services, reflecting the telecommunications landscape of the early 1990s.
target_audience: Hackers, phreakers, telecommunications enthusiasts, and security professionals interested in telephony systems.
short_summary: The article details various international toll-free and specialty phone service codes used in different countries, including dialing formats and potential access issues. It serves as a guide for understanding how to navigate these services across borders.
summary:
In this article, The Trunk Terminator outlines the dialing codes and formats for accessing toll-free and specialty services in various countries. The information is crucial for anyone looking to utilize international telecommunication services effectively. The author emphasizes the importance of understanding local dialing conventions, as these can vary significantly from one country to another. For example, in Australia, toll-free numbers are prefixed with '008', while in North America, they typically start with '1 800'.

The article also highlights the challenges associated with accessing these services, particularly the limitations on international calls to domestic toll-free numbers. The author provides insights into the costs associated with different services, noting that while some numbers are toll-free, others may incur charges depending on the provider and region. This detailed guide serves as a valuable resource for hackers and phreakers looking to exploit telecommunication systems, as well as for security professionals aiming to understand potential vulnerabilities in these services.
